module.title: Airspace Classification
module.description: National Airspace System classifications, operating requirements, and authorization procedures for UAS

lessons.title: Controlled Airspace: Class B, C, D
objectives: Identify Class B, C, and D airspace on sectional charts
Understand authorization requirements for each class
Know the visual indicators and dimensions of each class

sections.title: The National Airspace System
sections.content:
## The Big Picture

The National Airspace System (NAS) is divided into **controlled** and **uncontrolled** airspace. As a Part 107 pilot, your key question is: **in which airspace do I need authorization?**

| Need Authorization | Fly Freely |
|---|---|
| Class B | Class E (non-surface) |
| Class C | Class G |
| Class D | |
| Class E surface area (E2) | |

## Authorization Methods

**LAANC (Preferred):** Near-real-time approval through approved apps

**DroneZone:** Manual authorization — can take up to 90 days

sections.title: Class B Airspace
sections.content:
## What It Is

Class B airspace surrounds the **busiest airports** — LAX, JFK, ORD, ATL, DFW. These are major airline hubs with heavy jet traffic.

## Shape and Dimensions

Class B has the iconic **"upside-down wedding cake"** shape:

- **Surface area** extending from the ground up
- **Two or more layers** expanding outward at higher altitudes
- Each layer tailored to contain instrument approach/departure procedures

| Layer | Typical Radius | Floor | Ceiling |
|---|---|---|---|
| Inner (surface) | ~5 NM | Surface | 10,000 ft MSL |
| Middle | ~10 NM | ~2,000-3,000 ft | 10,000 ft MSL |
| Outer | ~15-20 NM | ~4,000-6,000 ft | 10,000 ft MSL |

## How to Identify on Sectional Charts

**Solid blue lines** forming concentric irregular shapes around the airport. Each ring is labeled with floor/ceiling (e.g., "100/40" = ceiling 10,000 ft, floor 4,000 ft).

## Part 107 Rules

- **Authorization required:** Yes — LAANC or DroneZone
- No sUAS operations without explicit ATC authorization
- Even with authorization, all Part 107 limits still apply

sections.title: Class C Airspace
sections.content:
## What It Is

Class C surrounds **medium-traffic airports** — busy enough for radar approach control but not as busy as Class B. Examples: Sacramento (SMF), Pittsburgh (PIT), Raleigh-Durham (RDU).

## Shape and Dimensions

Class C has a **two-layer structure:**

| Layer | Radius | Floor | Ceiling |
|---|---|---|---|
| Inner circle (surface) | 5 NM | Surface | 4,000 ft above airport |
| Outer shelf | 10 NM | 1,200 ft AGL | 4,000 ft above airport |

There's also an **outer area** extending to 20 NM where pilots can request radar service — but this doesn't require UAS authorization.

## How to Identify on Sectional Charts

**Solid magenta lines** forming two concentric rings.

## Part 107 Rules

- **Authorization required:** Yes — LAANC or DroneZone
- Same process as Class B

sections.title: Class D Airspace
sections.content:
## What It Is

Class D surrounds **smaller towered airports** — airports with an operating control tower but less traffic than B or C. Think regional airports or military airfields with towers.

## Shape and Dimensions

- **Horizontal:** Generally 4-5 NM radius
- **Vertical:** Surface to 2,500 ft AGL (varies by airport)
- Shape is roughly circular, may be modified for instrument approaches

## How to Identify on Sectional Charts

**Dashed blue lines** forming a roughly circular shape.

> **Memory aid:** Class **D**ashed = Class **D**

## Part 107 Rules

- **Authorization required:** Yes — LAANC or DroneZone
- If tower is part-time, Class D typically reverts to Class E or G when closed
- Check Chart Supplement for tower operating hours

bogeyman.message: Watch for part-time Class D! When the tower closes, airspace often reverts to Class E surface (dashed magenta). The exam may test whether you need authorization during tower hours vs. after hours.

lessons.title: Class E and Class G Airspace
objectives: Distinguish between Class E surface area and transition areas
Know when Class E requires authorization
Understand Class G as uncontrolled airspace

sections.title: Class E Airspace Types
sections.content:
## The Most Misunderstood Airspace

Class E is the most common controlled airspace and the **most misunderstood** by drone pilots. Not all Class E requires authorization — only the surface area does.

### Class E Surface Area (E2) — REQUIRES AUTHORIZATION

- Designated around airports with instrument approaches but no operating tower
- Extends from the **surface** upward
- Identified by a **dashed magenta line**

### Class E Transition Area (starts at 700 ft AGL) — NO AUTHORIZATION NEEDED

- Shown as **faded/shaded magenta** on the chart
- Since Part 107 limits you to 400 ft AGL, you're in Class G below this

### Class E En Route (starts at 1,200 ft AGL) — NO AUTHORIZATION NEEDED

- The "default" — unless otherwise depicted, Class E starts at 1,200 ft AGL
- Below 1,200 ft is Class G (uncontrolled)

bogeyman.message: This is the #1 chart-reading trap! Dashed magenta = surface = authorization needed. Faded/shaded magenta = starts at 700 ft = no authorization needed (you're flying in Class G below it).

sections.title: Reading Class E on Sectional Charts
sections.content:
## The Critical Distinction

| Class E Type | Starts At | Sectional Chart | Authorization? |
|---|---|---|---|
| E2 (Surface Area) | Surface | **Dashed magenta line** | **YES** |
| E5 (Transition, 700 ft) | 700 ft AGL | Faded magenta shading | No |
| E6 (En Route, 1,200 ft) | 1,200 ft AGL | Faded blue shading | No |

## Why Non-Surface Class E Doesn't Matter

Part 107 operations are limited to 400 ft AGL. If Class E starts at 700 ft or 1,200 ft, you're operating in Class G below that floor — no authorization needed.

## Exam Strategy

The exam will show you a sectional chart and ask if authorization is needed:

1. Look for **dashed magenta line** around the airport
2. If dashed magenta → Class E surface → **authorization needed**
3. If faded/shaded magenta → Class E starts at 700 ft → **no authorization** (you're in Class G at 400 ft)

sections.title: Class G Uncontrolled Airspace
sections.content:
## What It Is

Class G is **uncontrolled airspace** — ATC has no authority or responsibility here. This is where Part 107 pilots have the **most operational freedom**.

## Where It Exists

- Below Class E transition areas (below 700 ft or 1,200 ft AGL)
- In sparsely populated areas where controlled airspace isn't designated
- Anywhere not depicted as controlled on sectional charts

## Part 107 Rules in Class G

- **No authorization needed**
- All other Part 107 rules still apply:
  - Maximum 400 ft AGL
  - Minimum 3 SM visibility
  - Cloud clearance: 500 ft below, 2,000 ft horizontal
  - VLOS, daylight/night lighting rules

## Common Trap

Class G is the "default" for drone operations — but don't assume everywhere is Class G. Always check the sectional chart. And remember: even in Class G, you still need 3 SM visibility and cloud clearance. "Uncontrolled" doesn't mean "no rules."

lessons.title: Special-Use Airspace
objectives: Identify the six types of special-use airspace
Know which types prohibit operations vs. allow operations
Understand that CFAs are not depicted on charts

sections.title: Special-Use Airspace Overview
sections.content:
## What It Is

Special-use airspace (SUA) separates certain military and hazardous activities from other traffic. As a drone pilot, you need to know:

- Which types you **absolutely cannot enter**
- Which require **permission**
- Which just require **awareness**

## The Six Types

| Type | Can You Fly? | On Charts? |
|---|---|---|
| **Prohibited (P)** | **NO** — Never | Yes — blue hatching |
| **Restricted (R)** | With permission | Yes — blue hatching |
| **Warning (W)** | Yes, with caution | Yes |
| **MOA** | Yes, with caution | Yes — magenta hatching |
| **Alert** | Yes, with awareness | Yes — magenta hatching |
| **CFA** | Yes | **NO — not on charts** |

sections.title: Prohibited and Restricted Areas
sections.content:
## Prohibited Areas (P-xxx)

- **Can you fly here?** **NO. Never.**
- Established for **national security** (e.g., P-56 over White House/Capitol)
- Flight of **all** aircraft is prohibited
- **No waiver or authorization process** for Part 107
- Shown with **blue hashed lines** labeled "P" + number

> If a question mentions a prohibited area, the answer is always: you cannot fly there.

## Restricted Areas (R-xxx)

- **Can you fly here?** **Only with permission** from the controlling agency
- Contains hazardous activities (artillery, aerial gunnery, missiles)
- May be active full-time or only during certain hours
- You must get **written permission from the controlling agency** — LAANC does not apply
- Shown with **blue hashed lines** labeled "R" + number

> Restricted ≠ Prohibited. Restricted means you *might* be able to fly with permission.

sections.title: MOAs, Warning, Alert, and CFAs
sections.content:
## Military Operation Areas (MOAs)

- Separate military training from civilian traffic
- When active: high-speed maneuvers, aerobatics, combat training
- VFR flight is permitted but **use extreme caution**
- Check NOTAMs for active status
- Shown with **magenta hashed lines**

## Warning Areas (W-xxx)

- Similar to MOAs but extend over **international waters** (typically 3+ NM offshore)
- May contain hazardous activities
- Exercise extreme caution

## Alert Areas

- High volume of pilot training or unusual aerial activity
- **No restriction** on flight — but exercise extra vigilance
- Shown with **magenta hashed lines** labeled "A" + number

## Controlled Firing Areas (CFAs)

- Activities (artillery, missiles) are **suspended when aircraft are detected**
- Only SUA where the hazardous activity yields to traffic
- **NOT depicted on sectional charts** — they're self-regulating

bogeyman.message: Exam favorite: 'Which special-use airspace is NOT shown on sectional charts?' Answer: Controlled Firing Areas. They suspend operations when aircraft approach, so no chart depiction is needed.

lessons.title: TFRs, MTRs, and NOTAMs
objectives: Know how to read Military Training Routes
Learn how to obtain and interpret NOTAMs

sections.title: Temporary Flight Restrictions
sections.content:
## What TFRs Are

TFRs are **temporary airspace restrictions** that can pop up anywhere, anytime. They restrict all aircraft — including drones — from operating in the affected area.

## Common Triggers

- **Presidential/VIP movement** (most common)
- **Wildfires** ("If you fly, they can't" — operating near a wildfire TFR is a federal offense)
- **Sporting events** (NFL, MLB, NASCAR — typically 3 NM radius, surface to 3,000 ft)
- **Disaster relief** (hurricanes, earthquakes)
- **Space launches**
- **Special security events**

## How to Check for TFRs

1. **tfr.faa.gov** — official FAA TFR site
2. **B4UFLY app** — shows TFRs on a map
3. **LAANC apps** — integrated TFR alerts
4. **Flight Service** — 1-800-WX-BRIEF
5. **NOTAMs** — notams.faa.gov

## Part 107 Requirements

Under 14 CFR 107.47, Part 107 pilots must comply with all flight restrictions under Parts 91 and 99 — this includes TFRs. **Ignorance is not an excuse.** Check before every flight.

sections.title: Military Training Routes
sections.content:
## What MTRs Are

Military Training Routes are **low-altitude, high-speed corridors** where military aircraft fly below 10,000 feet at speeds exceeding 250 knots. This is one of the most dangerous environments for drone pilots.

## Route Types

| Prefix | Rule | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| **IR** (Instrument Route) | Flown under IFR | May have segments in clouds |
| **VR** (Visual Route) | Flown under VFR | Clear weather operations |

## The Number Tells You the Altitude

| Digits | Example | What It Means |
|---|---|---|
| **4 digits** | VR1234 | **All segments below 1,500 ft AGL** — highest risk |
| **3 digits** | IR567 | At least **one segment above 1,500 ft AGL** |

## How to Identify on Charts

Red arrows showing direction of flight, labeled with route designator (e.g., "IR205" or "VR1042").

## What to Do

Check NOTAMs or contact Flight Service (1-800-WX-BRIEF) for MTR activation status before flying near one.

bogeyman.message: Four digits = below 1,500 ft = maximum danger zone for drones. Three digits = at least part of the route is higher. This distinction is frequently tested!

sections.title: The NOTAM System
sections.content:
## What NOTAMs Are

NOTAMs (Notices to Air Missions) are advisories that alert pilots to hazards, changes, and special activities in the NAS. Checking NOTAMs is essential for preflight planning.

## How to Obtain NOTAMs

| Source | Access |
|---|---|
| **Flight Service** | Call **1-800-WX-BRIEF** |
| **Online NOTAM Search** | notams.faa.gov |
| **1800WXBrief.com** | Leidos Flight Service website |
| **LAANC Apps** | Most display relevant NOTAMs automatically |
| **B4UFLY App** | FAA's free app shows NOTAMs/TFRs |

## What to Look For

- **TFRs** in your area
- **Parachute jumping** activity
- **MTR activation**
- **Temporary obstacles** (cranes, construction)
- **Airspace changes**
- **Special events**

## Exam Tip

The exam will ask how to obtain NOTAMs. Classic answer: **Flight Service (1-800-WX-BRIEF)**. Also know online sources like notams.faa.gov.

lessons.title: Night Operations and Lighting
objectives: Know anti-collision lighting requirements for night operations

sections.title: sUAS Lighting Requirements
sections.content:
## The 2021 Rule Change

Before April 2021, Part 107 required a waiver for night operations. Now, night flight is permitted by default — but with specific equipment requirements.

## Anti-Collision Lighting Requirements

**At Night (sunset to sunrise):**

- Your sUAS must have **anti-collision lighting visible for at least 3 statute miles**
- The light must have a flash rate sufficient to avoid a collision
- The remote PIC may reduce (but NOT extinguish) light intensity if needed for safety

**During Civil Twilight (30 minutes before sunrise / 30 minutes after sunset):**

- Same anti-collision lighting requirements
- Light intensity may be reduced if in the interest of safety

## What Counts as Anti-Collision Lighting

- Strobe lights designed for sUAS use
- Must be visible from **3 statute miles** in clear conditions
- Must be **flashing**, not steady-burn
- Must be visible from all directions

bogeyman.message: "3 statute miles" is the magic number for anti-collision light visibility — same as the minimum flight visibility requirement. Easy to remember!

sections.title: Manned Aircraft Lighting
sections.content:
## Know the Lights to Stay Safe

Understanding manned aircraft lighting helps you see-and-avoid at night.

| Light | Color | Location | Meaning |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Position (nav) lights** | Red (left), Green (right), White (tail) | Wingtips and tail | Always on |
| **Anti-collision beacon** | Red or white rotating/flashing | Top/bottom of fuselage | High visibility |
| **Landing lights** | White (very bright) | Nose or wing | Approaching for landing |
| **Strobe lights** | White, high-intensity flashing | Wingtips | Enhanced visibility |

## What This Tells You

- **Red on left:** Aircraft moving left to right (you see left wing)
- **Green on left:** Aircraft moving right to left (you see right wing)
- **Red AND green visible:** Aircraft heading toward you
- **Only white visible:** Aircraft moving away from you
- **Bright landing lights:** Aircraft approaching your location — **take immediate action**

bogeyman.message: Red-Right-Returning: If you see a red light on the right side of an aircraft, it's coming toward you. The exam frequently tests this!

sections.title: Ground Hazards at Night
sections.content:
## Ground Structure Lighting

Many structures have obstruction lighting:

| Light Type | Color | Structure |
|---|---|---|
| Red steady-burning | Red | Towers, buildings (marks top) |
| Red flashing/strobe | Red/White | Tall towers (>200 ft AGL) |
| High-intensity white strobe | White | Very tall structures |

## Hazards WITHOUT Lighting

At night, many ground hazards become invisible:

- **Power lines and telephone wires** — rarely lit
- **Trees and vegetation** — no lighting
- **Fences and walls** — no lighting
- **Terrain changes** (hills, ditches)
- **Temporary structures** (construction equipment)
- **Water features** — hard to distinguish

## Mitigation

- **Scout during daylight** before night operations
- Use satellite imagery to identify hazards
- Maintain sufficient altitude to clear known obstacles
- Use obstacle avoidance sensors if equipped (but don't rely on them exclusively)
